prior_works.title: Statistical Reasoning with Imprecise Probabilities
prior_works.role: Foundational theory of credal sets and imprecise probabilities
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the theoretical basis for representing epistemic uncertainty via sets of probability distributions, which the paper instantiates as credal sets defined through relative likelihood.

prior_works.title: Likelihood
prior_works.role: Foundational likelihood-based inference and relative likelihood thresholds
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces relative likelihood and likelihood regions, underpinning the paper’s central idea of defining the set of ‘plausible’ models via a relative-likelihood threshold with interpretability.

prior_works.title: Statistical Evidence: A Likelihood Paradigm
prior_works.role: Likelihoodist evidence framework using likelihood ratios
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the evidential interpretation of likelihood ratios and practical thresholding principles that the paper leverages to trade off correctness and precision in credal prediction.

prior_works.title: Model Selection and Multimodel Inference
prior_works.authors: Kenneth P. Burnham, David R. Anderson
prior_works.role: Relative-likelihood-based model confidence sets and multimodel inference
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Operationalizes relative likelihood for selecting a plausible set of models (e.g., via ΔAIC and exp(−Δ/2)), directly motivating the paper’s construction of credal sets from models exceeding a likelihood threshold.

prior_works.title: The future of distributed models: Model calibration and uncertainty prediction (GLUE methodology)
prior_works.authors: Keith J. Beven, Andrew M. Binley
prior_works.role: Likelihood-threshold acceptance of behavioral models for uncertainty quantification
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Pioneers selecting an ensemble of ‘behavioral’ models by likelihood-based thresholds and propagating them to predictions, an immediate precursor to defining credal sets from plausible models.

prior_works.title: The Naive Credal Classifier
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrates practical credal prediction using sets of distributions in supervised learning, informing the paper’s goal of controllable correctness–precision trade-offs in predictive tasks.

prior_works.title: Bagging Predictors
prior_works.role: Ensemble methodology to approximate model variability
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the ensemble mechanism to generate diverse model candidates, which the paper modifies to approximate the credal set of likelihood-plausible models.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core innovation—defining credal predictions as the image of all models whose relative likelihood exceeds a threshold—sits at the intersection of imprecise probability theory and likelihood-based evidence. Walley’s foundational framework legitimizes representing epistemic uncertainty by sets of distributions (credal sets), paving the way for credal prediction as a target output. On the evidential side, Edwards and Royall establish relative likelihood and likelihood ratios as primary measures of statistical evidence, including interpretable thresholds that demarcate plausible hypotheses. Burnham and Anderson translate these principles into practical model selection and multimodel inference, where models within a relative-likelihood neighborhood (e.g., ΔAIC rules) form confidence sets—precisely the construct this paper reinterprets as a credal set of conditional distributions. The GLUE methodology by Beven and Binley provides a closely related precedent: accept an ensemble of ‘behavioral’ models using likelihood-based thresholds and propagate them to uncertainty bounds, which conceptually anticipates the paper’s likelihood-thresholded set of predictors. On the algorithmic side, Zaffalon shows how credal prediction can be operationalized in supervised learning, offering a concrete context for the correctness–precision trade-off. Finally, Breiman’s bagging gives the practical ensemble machinery to instantiate and approximate the set of plausible models; by suitably modifying such ensembles and filtering via relative likelihood, the paper constructs tractable approximations to credal sets with controlled informativeness. Together, these works directly scaffold the paper’s theoretical definition, interpretability of the threshold, and its ensemble-based approximation strategy.
